title: Thomas Partey makes noise but Atlético Madrid fail to break down Real Madrid
text:
In the end, there was no way through. Real Madrid’s fans once famously held up a mock classified advert requesting a “worthy rival for a decent derby”, and they got it: Real arrived at the home of their city rivals having won just two of the last 15 meetings between these two teams and they didn’t win this one either.

That they departed reasonably satisfied with another draw – Real have still only lost once in their last eighteen visits to the Vicente Calderón and the Wanda Metropolitano – reflects how much things have changed, how distant those days seem now. It also reflects the fact that with this result, they remain top of the league.

Between them, these sides spent almost €600m in the summer, but they produced a game of few chances, in which both managers looked for a way through but appeared more concerned with the other man not finding it.

Atlético Madrid 0-0 Real Madrid: La Liga – as it happened Read more

The last time the teams met, it finished 7-2 to Atlético in New Jersey. “What happened, happened,” Zidane had said; what would happen now would be different, everyone knew. This was tighter, tenser, and meant more; it was always likely to be, as was reflected in the inclusion of Federico Valverde in Real’s midfield in place of James Rodríguez. Within five minutes, Sergio Ramos left João Félix on the floor – and gestured for him to get up again. This was a battle for control which no one really won.

If there was a broad first-half pattern it ran: Atlético, Real, Atlético. João Félix shot wide when Diego Costa sent him running clear. Hazard escaped up the left, but his cross was cut out. And fairly harmless shots from Karim Benzema, Nacho and Toni Kroos drew three corners in little over a minute. Kroos then took the ball beautifully on the bounce, sweeping a bending, side-footer from 20 yards that Jan Oblak dived to push away.

In the middle of it all, Thomas Partey was the game’s outstanding midfielder and he sent a superb cross through the six-yard box which Costa couldn’t quite reach. He also retook control and, as Atlético advanced again, it was Kieran Trippier they most often sought. A wonderful pass from Thomas found him in the area, free. Options didn’t quite open before him, at least not with the speed he hoped, and Courtois reached out to stop his low ball seeking out Koke at the far post.

Thomas it had been too who teed up João Félix to hit a shot just wide from the edge of the area. Opportunities were limited, though, and Diego Simeone made his first change at the break, Ángel Correa replacing Vitolo and immediately dashing in to head over Costa’s chipped pass.

Correa brought electricity but it was Real who had the first clear chance when Eden Hazard found Nacho overlapping. Nacho’s cutback ran towards Gareth Bale, thundering into the area and the perfect shooting position. He opened up his body and hit the ball bending high into the south end, the roar from the fans there speaking of relief.

At the other end, Trippier’s cross – his ninth of the game – only just evaded Costa. Both sides looked for solutions, albeit without running excessive risks, and the changes came: Thomas Lemar, Luka Modric, Marcos Llorente, Rodríguez. In Atlético’s case, the changes were especially significant: Koke changed sides, Saúl went to left back, and Correa moved from right to centre. And yet the game didn’t move much, even though Modric immediately sent a ball across the face of goal. Saúl headed Koke’s corner just past the post.

Then Nacho’s inswinging cross was met by Benzema, but Oblak dived full length to make a sharp save low by the post. Lemar, Correa and Trippier combined to reach the byline but Koke couldn’t turn the shot goalwards at the near post. At the south end, they sang. On the pitch, they couldn’t score.
description: Atlético Madrid’s Thomas Partey weaved magic in midfield while Gareth Bale missed Real Madrid’s best chance in a tense 0-0 draw
